Award.AwardTitle: Bayesian Inference in Statistics and Statistical Genetics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the participation of junior researchers in the research conference "Bayesian Inference in Statistics and Statistical Genetics" to be held at Michigan Technological University in Houghton, Michigan, August 16-20, 2017. Bayesian inference for high-dimensional data has received considerable attention from researchers in a wide variety of fields, including climatology analysis, genomics and proteomics studies, time series analysis, and neuroimaging. Further, there is an increasing demand for Bayesian inference in other related fields due to the rapid evolution of high-performance computing.

The purpose of this conference is to stimulate research collaboration in the development, analysis, and application of statistical techniques for complex, high-dimensional data arising in real world applications. The conference will be an excellent forum for exchanging cutting-edge research results, highlighting current research trends and open problems, exploring visions of future work, and stimulating cross-disciplinary research in various areas. The conference will feature plenary talks given by internationally recognized specialists, invited presentations by junior researchers, and a contributed poster session. Additional information can be found at the conference website:
http://kliak.mtu.edu/2017/

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project outcomes report

The main aim of this project was to stimulate research collaboration in the development, analysis, and application of statistical techniques for complex, high-dimensional data arising in the real world applications. The conference consisted of about 70 participants (including ∼30 local participants) spanning the gamut of early-career and distinguished researchers. We paid special attention to diversify the conference participants and encourage participation of graduate students and underrepresented minorities. Thirty-seven participants were from 28 universities in 4 different countries: A quick break down of 37 participants is as follows: (i) 27 males and 10 females; (ii) 2 Africans; (iii) 22 junior researchers and graduate students, and (iv) 11 area-based diversity. Note that several participants may belong to multiple categories and some did not indicate any. 

The conference consisted of 8 distinguished lectures given by the plenary speakers and a series of presentations by invited speakers. The plenary and invited speakers were from a broad range of disciplines, including Applied Mathematics, Biostatistics, Computer Science, and Engineering. The planned sessions provided opportunities for established experts, junior researchers, and graduate students to present their latest research developments in statistical theory and applications, discuss new research trends and outstanding problems, and explore different visions for future work. Cross-disciplinary interaction was also fostered through ample free time for informal discussions among the participants. Our feedback from the conference participants indicates that the conference provided excellent opportunities for junior researchers and graduate students to learn about contemporary applications of statistical methods in a wide variety of disciplines, potentially fostering cross-disciplinary collaborations.
